name: Transference-Focused Therapy (TFT)
summary: Transference-Focused Therapy (TFT) is a structured psychodynamic therapy designed to treat borderline personality disorder (BPD) and other personality disorders by focusing on the patient’s relationship with the therapist as a way to understand and integrate fragmented self- and object-representations.
description: Transference-Focused Therapy (TFT), also known as Transference-Focused Psychotherapy (TFP), is a manualized, evidence-based form of psychodynamic psychotherapy developed by Otto Kernberg and colleagues. It is specifically designed to treat borderline personality disorder and other severe personality disorders. TFT works by exploring and interpreting the transference — the patient's projections and relational patterns as they emerge in the therapeutic relationship — to help patients integrate split and contradictory internal representations of self and others. Through consistent interpretation, patients gradually develop more coherent self-concepts, improved emotional regulation, and healthier interpersonal functioning.

metadata.training_required: Specialized training in TFP through accredited programs

off_label_uses: Complex trauma and chronic relational issues
contraindications: Patients unable to commit to long-term intensive therapy
clinical_metadata.safety_profile: Generally safe, but may temporarily increase distress as unconscious conflicts surface.
clinical_metadata.evidence_level: Strong for BPD, moderate for other personality disorders
clinical_metadata.research_support: Multiple randomized controlled trials and comparative studies show efficacy of TFP in reducing BPD symptoms, suicidal behaviors, and improving personality integration.

sections.text: TFT focuses on the therapeutic relationship as a mirror of the patient’s internal world. By analyzing the transference — how patients project their internalized self-other representations onto the therapist — the therapist helps integrate fragmented or split self-images and interpersonal patterns. Over time, this process fosters greater self-cohesion, emotional regulation, and improved relational capacity.

sections.preparation: Comprehensive diagnostic evaluation to confirm personality disorder and assess treatment suitability.
procedure: Two weekly sessions with a trained TFP therapist
Exploration of the therapeutic relationship and transference patterns
Interpretation of unconscious conflicts and relational splits
Gradual integration of fragmented self- and object-representations
sections.duration: At least 12 months, often extending to several years

sections.pre_session: Brief review of significant events since last session
sections.treatment_phase: Intensive exploration of transference, relational dynamics, and unconscious processes
sections.post_session: Reflection and therapist’s integration of themes for continuity

long_term: Integration of self and object representations

common: Increased distress during exploration of trauma and conflict
rare: Therapy-interfering behaviors such as withdrawal or acting out in session

relative: Inability to commit to frequent long-term sessions

screening_required: Structured clinical interview for personality disorders (SCID-II or SCID-5-PD)

studies: Clarkin, J. F., Levy, K. N., Lenzenweger, M. F., & Kernberg, O. F. (2007). Evaluating three treatments for BPD: A randomized controlled trial.
Doering, S., et al. (2010). Transference-focused psychotherapy vs. treatment by experienced community psychotherapists for borderline personality disorder: Randomized controlled trial.
sections.limitations: Requires high patient commitment; not widely available due to specialized training requirements.

sections.total_treatment_cost: High due to frequency and duration of treatment
sections.insurance_coverage: May be partially covered under psychotherapy benefits
sections.cost_effectiveness: Cost-effective for BPD compared to untreated chronic crisis and hospitalizations

concurrent_therapies: Group therapy for skills support (e.g., DBT skills groups)

sections.adolescents: Rarely used, though adaptations exist in some research settings.
sections.cultural: Requires cultural sensitivity in interpreting transference and relational dynamics.

items: TFP requires high structure and consistency, with a focus on managing therapy-interfering behaviors.
Evidence supports its efficacy in reducing suicidality and self-harm in BPD.
It is considered one of the empirically supported psychodynamic treatments for personality disorders.
